awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT:  High performance, regenerative windows for building energy reduction and clean energy production
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation - Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project offers broader environmental, societal, and commercial impacts through building energy savings, renewable power production, and pollutant reductions. Commercial windows significantly contribute to an increase in heating and cooling loads inside the building while affecting visual and thermal comfort to the occupants. The development of clean energy is an important priority as the growing population and new construction lead to a rise in fossil fuel use and anthropogenic emissions. This project is expected to improve on-site renewable energy production to help combat global warming. The US construction market for commercial windows is estimated at around $3 billion annually. With enhanced energy efficiency and power production, the proposed regenerative windows have the potential to save both upfront and operational cost by producing clean electricity and reducing cooling, heating, and artificial lighting load, making buildings more appealing to building owners, industry professionals, and stakeholders. Aesthetic enhancement of the system is expected to further increase widespread adoption of public use. The project is contributing to an energy-efficient, healthy living environment through aesthetically intriguing, functionally innovative windows.

This project seeks to develop a novel high-performance regenerative window integrated with climate responsive solar cells to improve on-site clean energy production and building energy efficiency.  The vertical surface of urban buildings offers a prime location to harness solar energy. Unlike traditional double-pane windows, the proposed windows are able to be optimized for various performance needs – energy savings, on-site power production, and user satisfaction. The system incorporates a closed air cavity where solar cells are installed in a conditioned, closed air space to prevent heat build-up, dust accumulation, and moisture formation resulting in high energy conversion efficiency and system longevity. In addition to the enhanced energy conversion efficiency and system longevity, the system is expected to yield high thermal performance, good shading efficacy, daylighting penetration, and acoustic insulation. The system is also designed to promote wide architectural application and user satisfaction by providing improved aesthetic appearance, and view-out and daylight illuminance, impacting the health, well-being, and productivity of building occupants.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Windows significantly influence architectural and energy performance, serving as vital interfaces between exterior and interior environments. Although Building Integrated Photovoltaic (BIPV) systems have advanced significantly, their application in architecture remains limited due to high upfront costs, low conversion efficiency, and unattractive appearances. Therefore, it is necessary to create innovative BIPV windows with more performative and beautiful designs than conventional BIPV. Our BIPV system integrates adaptable solar modules within a closed cavity facade, optimized for power generation and longevity. In addition, our system integrates hybrid circuit connections that outperform traditional circuit connections, especially under partial shadows. It also saves building energy use by utilizing solar heat control and providing excellent thermal insulation values, tailored to façade orientation and climate regions. While other common BIPVs such as spandrel BIPV or rooftop solar lack climate responsiveness and view-out capabilities, our BIPV aims at maximizing daylight access and views consequently enhancing occupant satisfaction. It promotes net-zero energy buildings while also serving as architectural elements like solar shades.

The broad impacts of our BIPV system encompass several areas.

Environmental benefits and wellbeing: Our BIPV systems have environmental and health benefits through on-site clean energy generation, lessening carbon emissions, reducing dependence on fossil fuels and sustaining efforts to combat climate change. On-site renewable energy lowers emissions and air pollution thus contributing to better air quality and public health. This will be a reduction which improves the wellbeing of people and the planet. Through green conservation practices sustainable energy ensures that there is reduced global warming hence benefiting future generations.

Economic benefits: These optimized solar installations provide significant cost savings through improved energy efficiency, lower bills, and reduced maintenance, enhancing their economic viability for commercial as well as residential users. When manufacturing renewable energy infrastructure, employment is generated in the areas of production, installation, maintenance and related services thereby providing new opportunities for job seekers within the local economies.

Energy security: Our system enhances local security by generating electricity from its own buildings rather than relying on distant sources for supplies. This autonomy protects against supply interruptions caused by resource scarcity or government restrictions on imports. A reliable, uninterrupted power supply is essential for any community, including existing homes and businesses.

During our project, we documented significant research findings that have been published and under review in various peer-reviewed journals and conference proceedings. These works enhance the understanding of BIPV systems within the wider scientific community while demonstrating our innovative approach toward net-zero architecture practice. For commercialization purposes, we have filed for patent protection on the novel BIPV façade systems and methods developed during this project (Application No. 17/070,124). This will give us competitive advantage in relation to market competition and bridge the gap between scientific research and practical application. The project allowed the team to engage in the customer discovery process, which served as a key step in the commercialization process. Additionally, it enabled us to get valuable advice from industry experts and stakeholders, thus opening up opportunities for partnerships aimed at bringing our innovation into broader use. Our project has fostered mentoring opportunities, enabling students to develop research skills and pursue academic growth and career paths. This has supported their education while cultivating new experts in renewable energy and sustainable building technologies.

In summary, our project has successfully addressed key challenges in the field of BIPV systems, leading to significant advancements in both intellectual merit and broader impacts. While doing so, the results obtained through our work not only contribute to scientific knowledge but also pave way for net zero building solutions that are beneficial to society as a whole.
